Vikings coach: 'This franchise is Teddy's'

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 10:55 a.m. EST December 10, 2014

Former Cardinals Calvin Pryor, left, and Teddy Bridgewater exchanged jerseys after the Vikings beat the Jets on Sunday.(Photo: AP Photo/Ann Heisenfelt)

CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Teddy Bridgewater fell into the Minnesota Vikings' starting quarterback job earlier this season because of an injury to Matt Cassel. It appears he'd need to suffer the same fate to lose that role anytime soon.

After the Vikings beat the New York Jets on Sunday thanks to a Bridgewater audible and 84-yard screen pass that led to a touchdown in overtime, coach Mike Zimmer said, "I think when Teddy decides to be the leader of the football team, because right now he's still feeling his way a little bit and his personality is just do what you do and do what you have to do, this franchise is Teddy's.

"I know that was a good headline for you."

Indeed.

RELATED: Bridgewater tosses game-winning TD in OT

The former University of Louisville quarterback had just completed 19 of 27 passes for 309 yards and a pair of scores in his ninth NFL start, bringing his two-week total to 34 of 48 for 447 yards, all with just one interception.

Bridgewater won the NFL's Rookie of the Week Award last week and is again nominated for the fan vote award (vote here: http://bit.ly/1sgESBw). Among his competitors are the Raiders' Derek Carr, Giants' Andre Williams, Panthers' Bene Benwikere and Steelers' Martavius Bryant.

The first-year player out of Miami is also up for the GMC "Never Say Never" Award (vote here: http://bit.ly/1vEjsyi) for the game-winning play.

    "The kid made a nice check to a screen pass, which you know was coming," Jets coach Rex Ryan said. "We have to make the tackle."

    IN THE C-J

    See a ton of U of L-Indiana basketball coverage game stories, columns, highlights and more video on our Cards page this morning after a 94-74 victory over the Hoosiers in the Jimmy V. Classic. (http://cjky.it/1ztHIc1)

    Up next for the University of Kentucky is Columbia, and during that game expect Karl-Anthony Towns to again strap on his scowl. Towns said he learned it from watching the demeanors of players such as Michael Jordan, Kobe Bryant and Karl Malone. (http://cjky.it/1Gjzwfi)

    Kentucky has the Nos. 1 and 4 teams in Division I. Notably, too, Bellarmine is up to No. 2 in the latest Division II coaches poll and with a matchup against No. 3 Florida Southern looming Saturday at Knights Hall. (http://cjky.it/1vOObO8)

    AROUND THE WEB

    Seth Davis, after making an upset pick of Indiana over U of L in last night's Jimmy V. Classic, noted that Cardinals fans were filling up his social media mentions because of the whiff. "My pick was just a bit outside," Davis quipped. (http://bit.ly/1x21IDQ)

    Matched up against No. 1 UK, Columbia's head basketball coach is hoping for an upset reminiscent of what NJIT recently did to Michigan. "Absolutely, we preach it all the time, that the differences aren't as great as you may believe if you read the papers or watch ESPN," Kyle Smith told SNY.tv. (http://bit.ly/166849R)

    The Sporting News' Mike DeCourcy wrote this week that college basketball attendance troubles could be solved if the season was shorter and started later. "I think it would be positive, being a one-semester sport," former UK coach Tubby Smith said in the article. (http://bit.ly/1qvmMQJ)
